name: tenyr
body:
### Usage
```
$ tas -ohello.to hello.tas
$ tld -ohello.texe hello.to puts.to
$ tsim hello.texe
hello, world !
```

### Overview
**tenyr** is a simple 32-bit computing environment with focus on simplicity of design and implementation.

**tenyr** currently provides

* an [instruction set architecture](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/wiki/Assembly-language)
* an [assembler / disassembler (tas)](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/wiki/Assembler)
* a linker (tld)
* an [architectural simulator (tsim)](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/wiki/Simulator)

shows progress on

* a [standard library](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/tree/master/lib)
* a [Forth environment](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/tree/master/forth)
* a [synthesisable HDL implementation](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/tree/master/hw/verilog)

and aspires to achieve

* a [C compiler](https://github.com/kulp/toycen)
* a novel operating system

The novel **tenyr** architecture is a two's complement, 32-bit, modified Harvard architecture. Everything possible is one word of 32 bits wide. The architecture design focuses on simplicity of design and implementation, with as many features as possible implemented in terms of simpler features. For example, there is no hardware stack support, although a set of assembly macros are provided for stack manipulation. For simplicity, **tenyr** is designed as a non-concurrent single-core architecture. It is intended that **tenyr** be useful as a didactic tool, though documentation may lag behind implementation.

**tenyr** is made available under the [MIT license](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/blob/master/COPYING), and is Copyright 2011-2012 [Darren Kulp](mailto:darren@kulp.ch) and [contributors](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/blob/master/CREDITS).
